content: Deep-fried battered banana or plantain A **banana fritter** is a [fritter](/wiki/Fritter) made by deep frying battered [banana](/wiki/Banana) or [plantain](/wiki/Cooking_banana) in hot [cooking oil](/wiki/Cooking_oil). It is a common dish across [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Cuisine_of_Southeast_Asia), [Madagascar](/wiki/Madagascar), and [South India](/wiki/South_Indian_cuisine), [Italy](/wiki/Italy), and [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil). ## Varieties ### Brunei Banana fritters are a traditional snack in [Brunei](/wiki/Brunei), where they are called *cucur pisang*. They are similar to *pisang goreng* in Indonesia and Malaysia. *Cucur pisang madu*, a variant of *cucur pisang* made with [honey](/wiki/Honey), are popular as a light afternoon meal (*minum petang*). ### Cambodia In [Khmer](/wiki/Khmer_language), banana fritters are called *num chek chien* (នំចេកចៀន). They are made by dipping flattened bananas in a thick mixture of [rice flour](/wiki/Rice_flour), [sesame seeds](/wiki/Sesame_seeds), [egg whites](/wiki/Egg_white) and [coconut milk](/wiki/Coconut_milk) seasoned with [salt](/wiki/Salt) and [sugar](/wiki/Sugar) and deep frying them in hot oil until crispy and golden. The Cambodian banana fritters are more savoury than sweet and are often eaten as a [snack](/wiki/Snack) with [coconut](/wiki/Coconut) [ice cream](/wiki/Ice_cream) as a popular accompaniment. A famous banana fritter shop in [Cambodia](/wiki/Cambodia) is *Chek Chean Pises* operating since 2000 that has two locations in [Phnom Penh](/wiki/Phnom_Penh) – at Mao Tse Tong Boulevard and Kampuchea Krom Boulevard. ### India #### South India *Vazhakkappam* or *pazham pori* ([Malayalam](/wiki/Malayalam_language): പഴം പൊരി), also known as *ethakka appam*, is a fritter food with ripened [banana](/wiki/Banana) or [plantain](/wiki/Cooking_banana) and [maida flour](/wiki/Maida_flour). A popular food item in [South Indian cuisines](/wiki/South_Indian_cuisine), especially in [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala), it is generally eaten as a [breakfast](/wiki/Breakfast) or a snack. It is called as *balekayi bajji* (ಬಾಳೆಕಾಯಿ ಬಜ್ಜಿ) in [Kannada](/wiki/Kannada), *vazhakkay bajji* in [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language), and *aratikaya bajji* (అరటికాయ బజ్జి) in [Telugu](/wiki/Telugu_language). *Pazham pori* is principally made from bananas or plantain. Plantains are slit lengthwise after peeling and is dipped into a batter made from all-purpose flour, salt, [turmeric powder](/wiki/Turmeric) and sugar. This is then deep-fried in oil until golden brown. In the other South Indian states of [Karnataka](/wiki/Karnataka) and [Tamil Nadu](/wiki/Tamil_Nadu), it is however prepared using [besan](/wiki/Besan) flour. In the state of [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala), banana fritters hold particular cultural and culinary significance and are commonly referred to as *pazham pori* or *ethakka appam*. They are typically prepared using ripe *nendran* bananas, which give the fritters a distinctive flavor and texture. Unlike many other types of fritters, they are traditionally served on their own often as an evening snack accompanied by tea and are not typically paired with curries or side dishes. *Pazham pori* is served usually along with tea or chai as a snack in the evening. In some restaurants in [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala) pazham pori is served along with [beef](/wiki/Kerala_beef_fry). ### Indonesia In [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), banana fritters are commonly known as *pisang goreng*.[*page needed*] They are often sold by [street vendors](/wiki/Street_food_of_Indonesia), In Indonesia *pisang goreng* are deep fried in ample of cooking oil; they might be coated with batter or not. [Plantain](/wiki/Cooking_banana) is often used instead of banana. Traditionally, some cultivars of banana such as *[pisang raja](/wiki/Latundan_banana)*, *pisang tanduk* and *[pisang kepok](/wiki/Saba_banana)* are the most popular kinds of banana used for pisang goreng. These banana cultivars have a mild sweet and sour flavor and firm texture that will not crumble upon being fried. *Pisang raja* however, has a softer texture and a fragrant aroma. The banana is often [battered](/wiki/Batter_(cooking)) and then [deep fried](/wiki/Deep_fried) in ample [palm oil](/wiki/Palm_oil). Pisang goreng might be battered or plain deep fried. The [batter](/wiki/Batter_(cooking)) most commonly uses a combination of [flour](/wiki/Flour), either [wheat](/wiki/Wheat_flour), [rice flour](/wiki/Rice_flour), [tapioca](/wiki/Tapioca) or [bread crumbs](/wiki/Bread_crumbs). Several recipes might add coconut milk or [milk](/wiki/Milk) and vanilla extract into the batter to add aroma. Most traditional street vendors will then sell them as is, without any additional ingredients or toppings. However, more upscale [coffee shops](/wiki/Coffehouse), cafes and [restaurants](/wiki/Restaurant) serve more sophisticated *pisang goreng* sprinkled with [powdered sugar](/wiki/Powdered_sugar), cinnamon sugar, [cheese](/wiki/Cheese), [jam](/wiki/Fruit_preserves), [condensed milk](/wiki/Condensed_milk), [chocolate](/wiki/Chocolate_ice_cream) or [vanilla ice cream](/wiki/Vanilla_ice_cream). In [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), it is consumed as a snack to accompany tea or [coffee](/wiki/Coffee), either in the morning or late afternoon break. Traditional *[warung kopi](/wiki/Warung)* (local coffee shops) often offer *pisang goreng* and other snacks, including fritters and *[kue](/wiki/Kue)* to accompany coffee or tea. Banana fritters along other kinds of [fritters](/wiki/Fritter#Indonesia) are sold on travelling carts or by street vendors throughout Indonesia. Other than pisang goreng, various kinds of ingredients are battered and deep fried such as [tempeh](/wiki/Tempeh), *mendoan*, [tofu](/wiki/Tofu) (*[tahu goreng](/wiki/Tahu_goreng)*), [oncom](/wiki/Oncom), [sweet potato](/wiki/Sweet_potato), [cassava](/wiki/Cassava) chunk, cassava [tapai](/wiki/Tapai), tapioca (*cireng*), [vegetables](/wiki/Vegetables) (*[bakwan](/wiki/Bakwan)*) and [breadfruit](/wiki/Breadfruit). Every region in Indonesia has developed various recipe for *pisang goreng* with a variety of different names, ingredients and cooking techniques. In [Bali](/wiki/Bali) for example, *pisang goreng* is called *godoh biu*, in [West Java](/wiki/West_Java) it is called *cau goreng*, in [Java](/wiki/Java) *gedhang goreng*, in [Sibolga](/wiki/Sibolga) *pisang rakit* and in [Pontianak](/wiki/Pontianak,_Indonesia) *pisang kipas*. *Pisang goreng* is usually sold together with other *gorengan* fritters including fried tofu and tempeh. However, *Pisang goreng Pontianak* are widely popular in Indonesia with certain retail outlets exclusively selling only this type of banana fritters. #### *Pisang goreng* variants Indonesia has many varieties of *pisang goreng*, including: *Pisang goreng kipas* or *Pisang goreng Pontianak*Refers to banana cut in the shape of a fan, battered, and deep fried. The term *pisang goreng Pontianak* is often used interchangeably with *pisang goreng kipas*, as both have a similar fan-like shape, but the former is often filled or served with [kaya jam](/wiki/Coconut_jam).*Pisang goreng pasir*Literally meaning "sandy fried banana", [bread crumbs](/wiki/Bread_crumbs) are added to the batter, resulting in grainy, crispy crumbs on the skin, giving it a similar texture to [croquette](/wiki/Croquette).*Pisang goreng kremes*Javanese *pisang goreng kremes* is quite similar to *pisang goreng pasir*, but with a different batter composition and a different frying technique. The batter coating is made of rice flour, vanilla extract, and coconut milk, deep fried in an ample of hot cooking oil, creating crispy and crunchy *kremes* granules in the coating, and resulting in a sweet, fragrant aroma.*Pisang goreng madu*Literally meaning "[honey](/wiki/Honey) fried banana", honey is added into the batter, and prior to serving honey is drizzled upon the fried banana. The color is rather dark due to the caramelised honey.*Pisang molen*Derived from Dutch influence in Indonesia, *pisang molen* literally means "milled banana". Unlike other batter-coated pisang goreng, *pisang molen* is wrapped around in tape-shaped thin pastry [dough](/wiki/Dough) prior to frying, creating a crunchy texture on the outside similar to pastry skin, while the banana inside remains moist and soft.*Pisang cokelat*Often colloquially abbreviated as *[piscok](/wiki/Piscok)*, it is a thin [crepe](/wiki/Crepe) skin filled with banana and chocolate [sprinkles](/wiki/Sprinkles) or [chocolate](/wiki/Chocolate) condensed milk, folded and deep fried in a similar fashion to making spring rolls. It is almost identical to the [Filipino](/wiki/Philippines) *[turon](/wiki/Turon_(food))*.*Pisang embal**[Kei](/wiki/Kai_Islands) pisang goreng* is similar to other batter-coated *pisang goreng*, but using *embal* ([tapioca](/wiki/Tapioca) or cassava starch) in its batter. It served with [sambal](/wiki/Sambal).*Pisang nugget*Small nugget-shaped fried banana. Its texture is akin to *pisang goreng pasir* in that it is coated in [bread crumbs](/wiki/Bread_crumbs), however it is much smaller in size, similar in shape to [chicken nuggets](/wiki/Chicken_nugget).*Pisang goreng telanjang*Literally meaning "naked fried banana", it is fried without any batter. Salted butter or margarine are added, and it may be topped with grated [cheddar cheese](/wiki/Cheddar_cheese). *Pisang raja* and *pisang tanduk* are the most suitable banana cultivars to be fried without batter.*Pisang goreng Manado**[Manado](/wiki/Manado_cuisine) pisang goreng* is similar to other batter-coated *pisang goreng*, except it is served with *[sambal roa](/wiki/Sambal)*, a spicy chili paste made of smoked roa fish and fresh chilies. - Pisang goreng ### Madagascar In [Madagascar](/wiki/Madagascar), where it is called *mofo akondro*, it consists of a whole or sliced banana—most often a cooking banana or a plantain—that is simply peeled and then dipped in a fluid, sticky batter. This batter, which serves as a coating, is traditionally made from wheat or rice flour, eggs, water or milk, and optionally sugar and a hint of vanilla. The coated banana is then immersed in a bath of hot oil and fried until the exterior is golden and crispy, and the banana inside is cooked and tender. Once fried, mofo akondro is primarily sold as street food. It is offered at a modest price by independent vendors, who sell it hot from market stalls or along busy thoroughfares, often to be eaten on the go as a quick and energizing snack. ### Malaysia and Singapore In [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), banana fritters are commonly known in the [Malay language](/wiki/Malay_language) as *pisang goreng*. Other names may include *cekodok pisang* and *jemput-jemput pisang*. The style of banana fritters commonly found in these countries is made by deep frying battered [plantain](/wiki/Cooking_banana) in hot [oil](/wiki/Cooking_oil). It is typically consumed as a snack in the morning and afternoon. They are often sold by street vendors, although it is also offered as a product at storefronts, dining establishments as well as Singapore's hawker centres. In Johor, Malaysia, **pisang goreng** is commonly served with **sambal kicap**, a spicy soy sauce dip that adds a savory and fiery twist to the traditional fried banana fritters. ### Myanmar A dish of banana fritter cooked in thick, spicy fish sause and served with rice is claimed to have been a favourite dish of the former royal family of Myanmar. ### Philippines There are numerous fried banana dishes in [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines). They are almost always made from [saba bananas](/wiki/Saba_banana), a native [cooking banana](/wiki/Cooking_banana) that is widely used in [Filipino cuisine](/wiki/Filipino_cuisine). *Pritong saging* are fried saba bananas (without batter) usually served with sugar or syrup. Bananas cooked with batter are a different dish known as *[maruya](/wiki/Maruya_(food))*, which are more commonly made mashed or sliced very thinly and spread into a fan shape. However, the most common Filipino street food dishes made from banana are [banana cue](/wiki/Banana_cue) and *[turon](/wiki/Turon_(food))*. Banana cue are fried bananas coated with caramelized sugar and served on skewers; while *turon* is a type of fried dessert *[lumpia](/wiki/Lumpia)* unique to the Philippines and is cooked in a crepe wrapper. ### Thailand *Kluai khaek* ([Thai](/wiki/Thai_language): กล้วยแขก, pronounced [klûa̯j kʰɛ̀ːk]), sometimes called *kluai thot* (กล้วยทอด, [klûa̯j tʰɔ̂ːt]), is a popular [Thai street snack](/wiki/Street_food_of_Thailand). *Kluai khaek* is made from fried, floured banana commonly topped with white sesame. For the word *kluai* in Thai means "banana" and *khaek* literally means "guest" and is a colloquialism used for Indians, Muslims or Hindus. Assumed that the reason it was called, probably because it was adapted from the recipe of those people. At present, it can be considered as street food that is easily found in general street stalls. Often sold with other types of snacks that have similar characteristics, such as *[khanom khai nok kratha](/wiki/Khanom_khai_nok_kratha)*, *khao mao thot*, fried taro, etc. An area famous for *kluai khaek* in [Bangkok](/wiki/Bangkok) is around [Lan Luang Intersection to Chakkraphatdi Phong Intersection](/wiki/Lan_Luang_Road), where it is referred to as [Nang Loeng](/wiki/Nang_Loeng) in the [Pom Prap Sattru Phai District](/wiki/Pom_Prap_Sattru_Phai_District). Here, there are many *kluai khaek* shops. The sellers will dress with aprons different colours vary according to each shop. They will carry banana bag, walk down the street and sell to those who drive through the streets and intersections in this area. In February 2018, [Bangkok Metropolitan Administration](/wiki/Bangkok_Metropolitan_Administration) (BMA) has banned this type of trade from being sold on the streets. ### Suriname In [Suriname](/wiki/Suriname), this snack is also known as *bakabana* (meaning fried banana in [Surinamese](/wiki/Sranan_Tongo)). ### Vietnam In [Vietnamese](/wiki/Vietnamese_language), banana fritters are called *chuối chiên*. They are based on the French dessert *banana flambée*. After deep frying, Vietnamese banana fritters are drizzled with [rum](/wiki/Rum) or [rice wine](/wiki/Rice_wine) and ignited to further crisp them. ### Italy In [Italy](/wiki/Italian_language), banana fritters are called *Banana alla Milanese*. ### Brazil In [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil), banana fritters are called *Banana à Milanesa*. - Food portal - Cambodia portal - Indonesia portal - Malaysia portal - Singapore portal - Thailand portal - Philippines portal - Vietnam portal - [Banana cue](/wiki/Banana_cue), Filipino version of fried bananas - [Fried plantain](/wiki/Fried_plantain), [African](/wiki/African_culture) version of fried bananas - [List of banana dishes](/wiki/List_of_banana_dishes) - [Banana chips](/wiki/Banana_chips)
title: Banana fritter
